title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
To Follow Along
These slides are available at https://viveks.me/talks/RIT-MathModeling/.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
section: “All Models Are Wrong, But Some Are Useful”
text:
“All Models Are Wrong, But Some Are Useful”


…all models are approximations. Essentially, all models are wrong, but some are useful. However, the approximate nature of the model must always be borne in mind….


— Box & Draper, Empirical Model Building and Response Surfaces, 1987

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
What Are Models Good For?


Models can corroborate a hypothesis by offering evidence to strengthen what may be already partly established through other means…
Thus, the primary value of models is heuristic: Models are representations, useful for guiding further study but not susceptible to proof.


— Oreskes et al, “Verification, Validation, and Confirmation of Numerical Models in the Earth Sciences”, 1994

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Models And Assumptions

XKCD Comic 2355
Source: XKCD 2355

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
section: Model Calibration, Validation, and Uncertainty Analysis

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
section: These Are Not Really Separate Processes
text:
These Are Not Really Separate Processes
Calibration, validation, and uncertainty analysis are not necessary separate “steps”, but often are mixed together in the process of model development and checking.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
What is Model Calibration?
Calibration involves choosing parameters, ideally based on some principled criteria.


[Calibration is] the selection of model parameters and structures to maximize the fidelity of the system model to observational data given model and computational constraints…


— Oreskes et al, “Verification, Validation, and Confirmation of Numerical Models in the Earth Sciences”, 1994

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Why Does Calibration Matter?

Models are necessarily simplifications of reality.
Missing or simplified processes may mean that direct translation of physical equation and parameters into the model do not yield the desired behavior.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Approaches to Calibration

Hand-Tuning: Manually adjusting parameters until the model output looks “right”.
Statistical Calibration: Wide category of statistically-based methods to find parameters which are most consistent with data.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Statistical Calibration
Statistical methods can involve finding point estimates or distributions of parameters (more on this later).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Formalizing Calibration
Let \(F(\mathbf{x}; \theta)\) be the simulation model function:

\(\mathbf{x}\) are the “control variables,” which are external forcings or variables affecting the simulation setting;
\(\theta\) are the “calibration variables” or “parameters.”

Then the goal of calibration is to identify parameters \(\theta\) which minimize the mismatch between \(F(\mathbf{x}; \theta)\) and data \(\mathbf{y}\).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Data-Model Discrepancy
As mentioned, all models will necessarily be wrong. We formalize this idea with the notion of discrepancy.
We can write the data as:
\[\mathbf{y} = z(\mathbf{x}) + \varepsilon,\]

\(z(\mathbf{x})\) is the “true” system state at control variable \(\mathbf{x}\);
\(\varepsilon\) are observation errors.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Data-Model Discrepancy
Then the discrepancy \(\zeta\) between the model simulation and the system is:
\[\zeta(\mathbf{x}; \theta) = z(\mathbf{x}) - F(\mathbf{x}; \theta).\]

Then the observations can be written as:
\[
\mathbf{y} = \underbrace{F(\mathbf{x}; \theta)}_{\text{model output}} + \underbrace{\zeta(\mathbf{x}; \theta)}_{\text{discrepancy}} + \underbrace{\varepsilon}_{\text{error}}
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Model Calibration and Discrepancy
Statistical calibration then involves specifying a probability model for the data, which can include:

Distributions/ranges for the calibration parameters;
A probability model for the discrepancy and observation errors.

Then the goal is to find parameters which maximize the likelihood (probability) of the data.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Example: Mean-Squared Error
Consider finding parameters \(\theta\) which minimize mean-squared error (MSE):
\[
\text{MSE} = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(y_i - F(x_i; \theta)\right)^2.
\]
This is an extremely common metric used for model calibration. Where does it come from?

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Example: Mean-Squared Error
It turns out this is the same thing as finding the parameters which maximize likelihood under the assumption of normally-distributed errors and discrepancy.
Assume that the errors are given by \(\mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)\). Then the likelihood of the data given the simulation model is:
\[
\mathcal{L}(\theta, \mathbf{y}; F) = \prod_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp(-\frac{y_i - F(x_i; \theta)^2}{2\sigma^2})
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Example: Mean-Squared Error
To maximize this likelihood, let’s take the logarithm:
\[
\begin{align}
\log \mathcal{L}(\theta, \mathbf{y}; F) &= \sum_{i=1}^n \left[\log \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} - \frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y_i - F(x_i; \theta))  ^2 \right] \\
&= n \log \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} - \frac{1}{2\sigma^2} \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - F(x_i; \theta))^2
\end{align}
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Example: Mean-Squared Error
If we ignore the constants (including the assumed error standard deviation \(\sigma\)), we’re left with wanting to maximize
\[-\sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - F(x_i; \theta))^2.\]

Maximizing this is equivalent to minimizing the negative:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - F(x_i; \theta))^2 = \text{MSE}
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
More Complicated Discrepancy-Error Structures
We can make similar estimatesfor more complex discrepancy structures (such as assuming normally-distributed errors and autoregressive discrepancy), but they may not result in “standard” error metrics.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
What is Model Validation?
Key Question: How do we know that our model is behaving as expected?

Won’t spend too much time on this, but can use a combination of graphical checks and quantitative metrics (\(R^2\), RMSE).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Connection Between Validation and Calibration
Model validation is often conditional on the calibration.
Have to look at model output from a particular parameter vector (or set of parameter vectors).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Residual Checking
Check 👏 Your 👏 Residuals!
Are they consistent with the assumptions made when building your probability model for the data?

For example:
We calibrated our model with MSE. Are our residuals normally-distributed?

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Mathematical Model
Rahmstorf (2007) proposed the following semi-empirical model for sea-level \(H\) response to changes to global mean temperature \(T\):
\[\frac{dH}{dt} = \alpha (T - T_0)\]

\(T_0\) is the temperature (\(^\circ C\)) where sea-level is in equilibrium (\(dH/dt = 0\))
\(\alpha\) is the sea-level rise sensitivity to temperature.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text: Plotting the Data

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Model Calibration
Let’s calibrate this model, assuming normal discrepancy (so minimize MSE). First, we need to discretize it:

\[
\begin{gather}
\frac{dH}{dt} = \alpha (T - T_0) \\[1em]
\frac{H(t+1) - H(t)}{\Delta t} = \alpha (T(t) - T_0) \\[1em]
H(t+1) = \alpha (T(t) - T_0) \Delta t + H(t)
\end{gather}
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Calibration Parameter Selection
This means we have three calibration parameters:

\(\alpha\),
\(T_0\),
\(H(0)\) (initial condition).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Calibration Results


Optimizing, we get:

\(\alpha \approx 1.86 \text{mm} / ^\circ C\)
\(T_0 \approx -0.97 ^\circ C\)
\(H(0) \approx -157 \text{mm}\).

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text: Visualizing Residuals

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
section: Are The Residuals Normal And Independent?
text: Are The Residuals Normal And Independent?

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Accounting for Autocorrelation
Let’s say we want to account for the autocorrelation in the residuals.
Where is this likely to enter into our discrepancy-error decomposition?

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Autocorrelated Discrepancy
Then our probability model might look like this:
\[
\begin{align}
y_t &= F(x_t; \theta) + \zeta_t + \varepsilon_t \\[1.0em]
\zeta_t &\sim \rho \zeta_{t-1} + \omega_t \\[1.0em]
\varepsilon_t &\sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_\varepsilon^2)\\[1.0em]
\omega_t &\sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_\omega^2)
\end{align}
\]

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Autocorrelated Discrepancy
We won’t go more deeply into this here – this doesn’t result in a “nice” error metric like the MSE.
But we could write out the probability distribution associated with this probability model (like we did with the MSE) and maximize, possibly treating the statistical parameters \(\rho, \sigma_\varepsilon^2, \sigma_\omega^2\) as uncertain as well.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Uncertainty Analysis
Everything that we talked about so far involve point estimates: we get single values of parameters which give us a “best fit” to the provided data.
When could this be a problem?


What if our data is itself uncertain?
What if multiple parameters are roughly equally consistent with the data?

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Uncertainty Analysis
To address these questions, we can quantify or characterize relevant uncertainties.
Many methods, lots to do and learn here.

title: Introduction to Model Calibration
text:
Thanks!
If you’d like to follow up:

Lab Website: https://viveks.bee.cornell.edu
Email: viveks@cornell.edu

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
To Follow Along.
These slides are available at https://viveks.me/talks/Dartmouth-CRM-2023-MORDM/.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
MORDM Overview

Overview of Multi-Objective Decision-Making
Source: Kasprzyk et al (2013). Many objective robust decision making for complex environmental systems undergoing change. Environmental Modelling and Software, 42, 55–71. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2012.12.007

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
MORDM Combines Several Concepts


Tradeoff Analysis
Multi-Objective Optimization
Robustness and Scenario Discovery



These do not need to be combined into a joint framework (MORDM), but are useful for a broad array of analyses.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
section: Decision-Making Often Involves Navigating Multiple Objectives/Metrics
text:
Decision-Making Often Involves Navigating Multiple Objectives/Metrics

Different stakeholders often have different priorities, values, and objectives.
Classical prescriptive approaches:

Post-hoc analysis
Formulate as constraints
Combine into a single utility function

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Multiple Objectives in CRM

Characteristics of Problems
Source: Keller et al (2021). Climate risk management. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences, 49(1), 95–116. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-earth-080320-055847

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
section: …But What If We Don’t Know Thresholds/Weights?
text:
…But What If We Don’t Know Thresholds/Weights?
Often it is not a priori clear what relevant constraints or utility weights ought to be (or can be).
We may also not know which objectives are in tension with each other.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
section: Tradeoffs Can Be Understood through Exploratory Analyses
text:
Tradeoffs Can Be Understood through Exploratory Analyses
We can search the outcome space to understand:

Which objectives are synergistic/antagonistic;
What the achievable ranges of these objectives are.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Managing Climate Change





Climate Risk Management Levers




Source: Keller et al (2021). Climate risk management. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences, 49(1), 95–116. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-earth-080320-055847

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Mitigation vs. SRM

Scatterplot of CRM Objectives
Source: Marangoni et al (in review), Robust Solar Radiation Management Strategies to Keep Global Temperature Rise Well-Below 2°C

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Mitigation vs. SRM

Parallel Axis Plot of CRM Objectives
Source: Marangoni et al (in review), Robust Solar Radiation Management Strategies to Keep Global Temperature Rise Well-Below 2°C

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Dominated and Non-Dominated Solutions
However, many possible solutions will inevitable be dominated: they are outperformed across all possible objectives by some other solution.
A solution is non-dominated if the only way to improve with respect to one objective is to deterioriate with respect to another.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Illustrating Non-Dominated Solutions





Space of All Solutions






Dominated vs. Non-Dominated Solutions

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Dominated Solutions and Pareto Fronts
The set of non-dominated solution is called the Pareto front.
For most interesting problems, the Pareto front is impossible to find analytically.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Finding Pareto Fronts
The best we can typically do is to find an approximate Pareto front using a Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithm (MOEA).

But:
Do we actually think the “optimal” solution from our model is the real-world optimum?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
MOEAs and Convergence
As EAs are heuristic methods, need to be careful about convergence.

Compare results with multiple seeds;
If you aren’t sure you’ve run it long enough, run it longer.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
section: Once We Have A Pareto Front…
text:
Once We Have A Pareto Front…
…We can:

Identify thresholds;
Select and analyze decision alternatives

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Mitigation vs. SRM

Parallel Axis Plot of CRM Objectives
Source: Marangoni et al (in review), Robust Solar Radiation Management Strategies to Keep Global Temperature Rise Well-Below 2°C

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Decision-Making and Uncertainty
Decision frameworks often simplify representations of uncertainties to facilitate optimization.
This can involve:

Optimizing with respect to a “best estimate”;
Assuming a single probability distribution to compute moments or estimators.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Deep Uncertainty
But often, uncertainties are deep: there is no consensus probability distribution, and outcomes can be driven by the choice of distribution.

For example:

What will future CO2 emissions be?
How will future changes to technology impact energy use?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Projecting CO2 Emissions





Projections of future CO2 Emissions




Source: Srikrishnan et al (2022). Probabilistic projections of baseline twenty-first century CO2 emissions using a simple calibrated integrated assessment model. Climatic Change, 170(3), 37. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-021-03279-7

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
CRM and Deep Uncertainty

Characteristics of Problems
Source: Keller et al (2021). Climate risk management. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences, 49(1), 95–116. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-earth-080320-055847

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Robustness and Deep Uncertainty
If we have to make these assumptions, how can we understand the robustness of a resulting solution?
In this context, robustness refers to the ability of a system to achieve “good” outcomes under deviations from the design assumptions.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
What Is Robustness?
More formally:


[Robustness is] “the insensitivity of system design to errors, random or otherwise, in the estimates of those parameters affecting design choice”


– Matalas and Fiering (1977); via Herman et al (2015)

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
What Are “Good” Outcomes?
Important to be specific: there are many different ways to conceptualize and measure robustness.

Ability to achieve a threshold across different states of the world?
Degradation from “optimal” outcome under perfect information?
Something else?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: SRM vs. Mitigation

Robustness of CRM Strategies
Source: Marangoni et al (in review), Robust Solar Radiation Management Strategies to Keep Global Temperature Rise Well-Below 2°C

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Robustness Overview





Robustness Taxonomy




Source: Herman et al (2015). How should robustness be defined for water systems planning under change? Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management, 141(10), 04015012. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)WR.1943-5452.0000509

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Needs For Robustness Analysis





Framework for calculating robustness metrics




Source: McPhail et al (2018). Robustness Metrics: How Are They Calculated, When Should They Be Used and Why Do They Give Different Results? Earth’s Future, 6(2). https://doi.org/10.1002/2017EF000649

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Examples of Robustness Metrics

Regret: penalize deviation from optimum or baseline.
Satisfycing: measure how often outcomes achieve thresholds.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
section: What Drives Outcomes (Or Lack of Robustness)?
text:
What Drives Outcomes (Or Lack of Robustness)?
Once we have done our exploratory or robustness analysis, it’s likely that many states of the world do not perform adequately.
Two main tools for understanding which scenarios lead to different outcomes (and why):

Sensitivity Analysis
Scenario Discovery

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Sensitivity Analysis


Sensitivity Analysis involves identifying or ranking the model factors that most (or least) influence model outputs.




Uncertainty Characterization E-Book Logo



Reed et al (2022). Addressing Uncertainty in MultiSector Dynamics Research, https://uc-ebook.org/.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Goals of Sensitivity Analysis

Goals of Sensitivity Analysis
Source: Reed et al (2022). Addressing Uncertainty in MultiSector Dynamics Research, https://uc-ebook.org/.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Types of Sensitivity Analysis
Sensitivity analyses can be broadly categorized as local or global.

Local SA: Vary uncertain factors around reference value(s)
Global SA: Vary uncertain factors across entire range.

Can also vary factors one-at-a-time or jointly.

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Baseline CO2 Emissions





Global Sensitivities for CO2 Emissions Model




Source: Srikrishnan et al (2022). Probabilistic projections of baseline twenty-first century CO2 emissions using a simple calibrated integrated assessment model. Climatic Change, 170(3), 37. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-021-03279-7

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Key Considerations for SA

Local vs. Global/OAT vs. Joint
How many model evaluations do you need/what is the computational complexity of the model?
What range/distribution is being used for each factor?
What is the design of experiments/sampling strategy?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Scenario Discovery
Scenario Discovery refers to the identification of consequential states of the world/scenarios.
For example:

What states of the world result in a loss of adequate performance/outcomes?
Are there different modes/clusters of similar outcomes?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Approaches for Scenario Discovery

Clustering
Machine Learning Classifiers (PRIM, CART, SVMs, ANNs)

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Example: Water Scarcity

Scenario Discovery for Water Scarcity
Source: Birnbaum et al (2022). Drivers of Future Physical Water Scarcity and Its Economic Impacts in Latin America and the Caribbean. Earth’s Future, 10(8), e2022EF002764. https://doi.org/10.1029/2022EF002764

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Key Questions for Scenario Discovery

Is the discovery of “types” of outcomes, or do you have a classification (acceptable/not)?
What next? How do we communicate/illustrate/synthesize the results?

title: Introduction to Multi-Objective Robust Decision Making (MORDM)
text:
Discussion Points

How can we incorporate these concepts into projects/proposals?
Are there valuable training resources/opportunities for students/postdocs?
How to incorporate as part of a stakeholder-driven project?

Key challenges: communication and interpretability.

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
GHG Emissions Cause Warming






  
    
  



  
    
  



  
    
  


































  
    
  



  
    
  



  
    
  

































Source (left): Global Carbon Budget 2022, Friedlingstein et al (2022)
Source (right): HadCRUT5

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Warming Causes Diverse Risks

Climate Risk Map
Source: Four Twenty Seven and the New York Times

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
section: Projected Impacts Are Highly Dependent on Future Emissions
text:
Projected Impacts Are Highly Dependent on Future Emissions

Sea Level Rise Projections
Source: IPCC AR6 Working Group 1, Technical Summary

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
What Are Future Emissions Scenarios?





CMIP6 SSP-RCP Scenarios



Source: O’Neill et al (2016)


We use a handful of scenarios (the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways-Representative Concentratio Pathways, or SSP-RCP scenarios) for future emissions and radiative forcing.

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Why Quantify Scenario Uncertainty?





Risk Taxonomy



Source: Simpson et al (2021)



Risk is hazard times consequences, not just consequences.
Given resource and political limits, important to understand what future scenarios are more or less plausible.

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Uncertainty Quantification: Caution Required!

Uncertainty quantification under these “deep” uncertainties necessarily involves subjective judgements.
Essential to be transparent and analyze sensitivities to different choices!

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Key Questions


What are the implications of historical dynamics on probabilities of scenarios of future CO2 emissions?
How does emissions uncertainty interact with geophysical uncertainty when projecting climate impacts?

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
“Baseline” Emissions Projections
Due to the reliance on historical data, we can only loosely consider future mitigation policies.
But this still provides us with a baseline that can be used to understand future emissions trends.
The results in this paper are from Srikrishnan et al (2022), Climatic Change.

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Model Structure



















Mixture of four emitting technologies:

Preindustrial (no emissions)
“Early”/High-emitting Fossil
“Late”/Low-emitting Fossil
Renewable

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Model Structure



















Assume economic growth levels are constrained by fossil fuel availability unless the economy decarbonizes prior to exhausting fossil fuels.

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Correlated Priors Require More Care



We can place (weakly) informed priors on individual parameters, but many are actually correlated.
Need to constrain current energy technology shares.





Schematic of Probabilistic Inversion



Source: Fuller et al (2017)

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Overview of Calibration Data


Population and economic growth data from 1820–2020 from the Maddison Project and the World Bank
Fossil emissions from 1820–2020 from Boden et al (2017) and the Global Carbon Project
Expert assessments of 2100: population (UN), economic output (Christensen et al (2018)), CO2 emissions (Ho et al (2019))
Energy fuel share data from BP World Energy Outlook (2020)

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Statistical Model
We use a VAR(1) model for discrepancies between the simulation model output (\(M(\mathbf{\theta})\)) and data (\(\mathbf{z}\)) as well as independent observation errors:
\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf{z}_t &= \mathbf{M}(\theta)_t + \mathbf{x}_t + \varepsilon_t\\[0.5em]
\mathbf{x}_t &= A\mathbf{x}_{t-1} + \omega_t
\end{align}
\]

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts

title: Navigating (Deep) Uncertainty in Modeling Climate Impacts
text:
Motivating Questions

What are the relative impacts of emissions and geophysical uncertainties on sea levels?
How does delaying decarbonization impact extreme sea level outcomes?

These results are in prep, led by Chloe Darnell (graduated M.S. student).
